ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a solid and relatively thorough foundation in multivariable calculus, including partial derivatives, line integrals, surface integrals, and triple integrals, all of which will have useful applications in other fields.
You can expect to develop quantitative reasoning skills related to multivariable calculus. This course is useful for continuing math or other related subjects at Yale.
Line integration
I learned a lot about calculus functions of several variables and was able to problem solve and apply my knowledge in different ways.
double and triple integrals and other multi variable cslculus material
multivariable calculus
I learned multiple integrals, partial derivatives, and more.

I believe I solidly grasp the concepts of line/surface integrals in terms of the math and the physics applications, which is crucial to me as an intended physics major. I often saw the concepts of MATH 120 in use in my other courses simultaneously as we were learning the material, and this greatly aided my understanding.
I learned about many new applications of calculus in a three-variable setting.
Multivariable calculus: 3D, differentiation, line/surface integrals, algorithms in choosing techniques etc.
Visualizing problems in 3D, double/triple integrals, Stokes/Greens/Divergence Theorem, spherical/cylindrical coordinates
I have learned how to visualize and analyze mathematical situations in a 3-D context.
I developed my understanding of calculus and applying this in 3d. I learnt many new methods.
I think time management, largely due to weekly psets and pre-class quizzes, was emphasized. I feel stronger in this regard.
This class taught me a very methodical approach to learning multivariable calculus. I overall learned a lot.
I thoroughly learned how to compute and think about three dimensional integrals, how to utilize the del operator, how to use specific theorems, how to apply those theorems, and more.
I learned how to approach math in a different way. Rather than just plug and chug with the formulas, I have to really learn the concepts in order to figure out how to apply the formulas
calculus

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I actually liked the redundancy between the pre-class videos and the lectures themselves; having the opportunity to see the same content taught in slightly different ways two times often made it easier to understand tricky concepts. There were some discrepancies in the style of teaching and methods taught between the different sections that could create confusion or difficulty on the problem sets, however.

Strengths: very clear grading policies & assignments, good layout of course, Pablo is a great lecturer and gives very clear explanations
Weaknesses: the peer tutors often do not know how to solve your psets (go directly to your prof instead)

I think this course is very informative, but I don't love the fact that it is very computational. Formulas and facts are often thrown at you with little explanation. Therefore, it isn't easy to remember the concept because you don't know where it came from. Furthermore, although I appreciated having a cheat sheet during the exam, I don't feel like I learned the content of the course as well because I wasn't forced to memorise its content.

It was good at teaching the content to know, but I wish there were more practice problems in addition to Ximera. Sometimes, Ximera doesn't give you the step-by-step solutions, so if you're stuck on a topic, it's hard to get more practice.
some parts taught really quickly for students who had no prior experience in multi variable calculus and physics
The course is organised so that you learn the content before going to class, which is both a strength and weakness depending on the student
I enjoyed the speed of lecture and appreciated the example problems we did in class.

One significant strength was the format of the lectures, including derivations, pictures/physical explanations, and plenty of in-class practice problems. The variety of instruction methods bolstered my understanding of the math principles. Additionally, the psets and practice exams were very representative of the exam difficulty and were immensely helpful in preparing for both midterms and the final; I also took advantage of the Ximera site for practice problems - in short, there was no shortage of practice.

Strengths: pre-class videos to introduce new materials before lecture, problem sets applied what we learned, problems during class/interactive lectures
Weaknesses: test difficulty did not always match difficulty of practice tests

Strengths: excellent structure, a lot of resources, grading method varies to play in your favour, cheat sheet allowed on exams. Weaknesses: high weekly workload despite the exams weighing 85% of your final grade.

Strengths: very thorough, lots of supplemental practice, sufficient preparation for course exams. Weaknesses: highly dependent on pre-class videos, unreasonably quick pace, frequent PSETs (sometimes 2 in a week)
This course is great at building a foundational understanding of 3-D mathematics. At times, however, the course feels too intensive.
I think its a very well organized course.
I thought it was a very good course. I think the psets often felt more time-consuming than learning provoking. Long integrals comprised most of my time rather than actual material knowledge.
Before tests problem sets would be given with only 4 days to complete them. That often was very stressful because they normally were during peak mid term times.
I feel that this course was fairly good overall. I have no complaints.
The tests difficulty completely unmatched the practice exams - which were very easy

Strengths- The course is challenging and requires you to critically think about the questions before approaching them
Weakness- Some concepts aren't taught very well or they could be taught in a more simpler way.
good

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It is a very challenging course, but it offers a great understanding of multivariate calc. However, if you are just an Econ major, you will be well-served by taking Math 115 or 118.
I would recommend taking it because it opens up a lot of opportunities as a prerequisite for advanced classes in math and other departments.
Yes, if you need it as a requirement, you can do well if you put in the effort (if not a major requirement, take something more fun)

I would recommend because you learn concepts that you will need in physics, math and econ but I would not recommend for it's very interesting content. The level of professors varies wildly, so the course can either go very well or very badly.
Yes, I'd recommend the course if you'd like to learn more about calculus and applications that will help you in other subject areas.
yes for your major. otherwise no
Yes, I would, as I think it helps give a strong background in multi variable calculus that can be used in other fields.

Yes, I believe it provides a solid foundation for not just a math future but a future in the physical sciences. It is also very satisfying upon the course wrap-up to look back on all the formulas we have learned and see how they connect. The professors are also always there to help and provide amazing practice resources, including full review sessions for the exams.
I would recommend this course! It is an interesting, well-taught math class with a good but not-overwhelming workload relevant to the real world. Though the tests are stressful, it is still worth it.
Yes
Yes; it provides a solid foundation to multivariable calculus, which has lots of applications in a number of fields
I would definitely recommend this course to other students as it allows for a strong understanding of integrals.
No if they dont have to take it
Yes I would as I enjoyed it but I would warn them about the level of work and inform them that they shouldnt do it unless they have a strong understanding of calculus already.
Yes, but only if necessary to a major or higher studies. Calculus is never that fun.
Yes. It is a good class and important for your major. I also believe that a strong understanding of calculus is important for ones life.
Yes, especially if you are a stem major
I would recommend this course to students who have an interest in math or physics. I think this course is very useful in those fields.
yes
